Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 12:01PM LINDAGARSIDE wrote: Hi Alison, I, like you, was prepared to have my entire breast removed.  I did not want to risk the cancer coming back.  My surgeon was very calm and told me that if I had a lumpectomy and radiation, the chance of cancer coming back was 8%.  If I had a masectomy and no radiation then the chance of cancer returning was 8%.  (My tumor was just about 2 cm). I've now had a lumpectomy and will be having radiation soon.  There was no lymph involvement and lucky for me I am Stage 1 and Grade 1 and didn't have cancer in my margins.  I can honestly say that looking at where the lump was removed (they took out 10 cm) you can hardly tell a difference.  It's amazing really. What worked for me may not work for you.  Everyone does what they need to do, for their own personal reasons. While some things are really outside of your control (like the cancer deciding to come back or not), there are some things you can control.  You can choose what course of action or battle plan you are going to take. Don't make a quick decision.  Start to read and study as though your life depended on it and then make an informed choice...for YOU.  Everyone's situation is unique and there are probably none of us that have exactly the same diagnosis with exactly the same grade/stage etc etc. Know that you are not alone and we are all here (not that any of us wanted to belong to this lovely club...LOL) for you.   Please take deep breaths and start to do research research research... Good luck to you...and God bless.
Posts.Title: help needed alison34 icey

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2010 07:14AM - edited Jan 19, 2010 07:41AM by LINDAGARSIDE Hells Bells.  Enough already....cancer be gone and fear be gone.  We choose to live fearless and with joy.  This includes our bookgirl.  (I am very angry with cancer right now!)

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2010 10:36PM LINDAGARSIDE wrote: Hi Renee...congratulations on completing your rads.  Yay for you!  Whoo Hooo. I am wondering about something and if you don't know the answer have you seen this discussed much at this site? I am probably going to take tamoxifen but I was wondering how long I will have to take it (I am 58) and what would happen if I stopped taking it after awhile.  I will certainly ask my oncolgist these things as well but I see you are a nurse and can't help but wonder what you think of my idea. I do not yet know my Her status or my ONC score.  I am still in the waiting line up as my surgery (lumpectomy) was only Januray 8th. Again...congratulations and thank you for your time.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 10:27PM - edited Jan 15, 2010 10:28PM by LINDAGARSIDE Keno41:  Hi and thank you for your note.  My surgeon (and research confirms) that a lumpectomy and radiation will give you the same chance as a MX....but I believe you must consider the age of the patient as well as what is feeding the tumor.  If I was pre-menopause, then I would have probably had a more aggressive approach.  Due to my age (a young 58) and the size of my tumor (1cm by 2cm) and that it was 100% estrogen positive, the surgeon said I'd have the same chance either way.  If the tumor was not estrogen positive or if I was pre-menopause, she may have suggested a MX.  I have to say though...regardless of what anyone else says...I've made up my mind that if my margins are not clear or cancer was found in my lymph glands...I will be requesting a MX for the right breast.  I have now heard of many patients who have had their breast(s) removed but the cancer has come back...because it can that's why.  :-(  Musiclover: Hi, and thank you for your note.  It sounds as though the pathologist had some sort of insight to what your cancer was going to do.   I'm starting to understand that cancer is like teenagers.  You never know what is going on, and why bad behaviour is happening...and then for no reason at all, things change.  Sometimes for the good and sometimes for the bad.  You don't like the cancer/kids at all and wish it/they would just get lost.   But you know the cancer/kids are yours and you have to deal with it.....ughhhhhhhhhh  LOL.  :-)
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2010 10:08PM LINDAGARSIDE wrote: I just started to take tamoxifen about a week ago and have not yet started my rads.  Will commence rads on March 8th. (Surgery was January 8th). The only side effect I've noticed so far is my appetite has actually decreased and I've got a small amount of white discharge which I understand is common. I have night sweats but had them anyway (I'm 58) so nothing new there.  Other than that....I can't tell that anything much is different in my life...other than the cancer of course.  LOL.  Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 02:28PM LINDAGARSIDE wrote: Hi Musiclover, thank you for your note.  I appreciate everything you've gone through and after hearing your story, I think I would have done the same thing.  When I first knew I had IDC, I told the surgeon, "Cut them both off" (I am 58 years old).  I said, "I don't need either of them".  She looked at me calmly and said, if we do that, your chance of recurrance is 8%.  If I do a lumpectomy and you have the radiation, your chance of a recurrance is 8%.  That is when I decided to go for the lumpectomy.  We do back to the surgeon this Monday for the pathology report from the surgery (which was done on January 8th..a week ago today).  If the surgeon tells me they have to do more surgery as they realize more cancer is evident...I will be insisting on a MX.  Not sure if I need a double MX as no cancer signs on the left breast.  I also had an MRI which shows on the left breast a benign 5mm smooth node.  My surgeon said these are common and are not cancerous.  I sure hope she is right!  I guess I will be getting my score when I meet with an oncologist...but who knows...after Monday I may be needing to meet with the surgeon again...oh my goodness...what a state of affairs we've all landed in together.  Where has our normal lives gone to?  It seems like only yesterday I wasn't thinking about all of this....LOL.  You really do have to laugh because if you don't...when will the tears stop?  Take care and again, thank you for your note...it is insightful.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2010 06:57PM LINDAGARSIDE wrote: Hi Janet.  I am so sorry for the loss of your dear husband.  It sounds as though the two of you were very tight.  I can visualize him watching you as you deal with what is on your plate right now.  Perhaps if you close your eyes and visualize him right there, encouraging you on as you move forward, it will help.  Because Janet, you must carry on and fight the good fight.  You have children and us for support, right?  I too was the first in my family to have breast cancer.  It's quite a shock as we never expected anything like this...there are 5 girls in my family and numerous aunts.  We've had some other cancers...but not breast cancer.  Lucky me.  LOL. So now you are going to meet your surgeon?  Or the oncologist?  Janet, there are so many treatments and strategies for dealing with so many types and stages of breast cancer.  Try to keep looking forward, one step at a time.  You will find the waiting game the hardest part of everything...at least that is certainly been my experience and from what I can tell...from many others as well.  Janet, welcome to this club you never thought you would belong to.  You've got excellent company and we are all in this together.  Hang in there, sister!
Posts.Title: 1st in my family for this MommaChi MommaChi
